none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. D. Snead, October 21, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. D. Snead, October 21, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 10 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

ALBERT MANTOOTH, President,
C. N. SNEED, Secretary.

J. D. GANN, Cor. Secretary.
➵ OFFICE OF ➷

JOSEPH KERR, Vice-President.
C. MANTOOTH, Treasurer.

ANGELI[NA] IMMIGRATION SOCIETY.

Homer, Texas, Oct 21" 1881

[Body]

Pres. James
A.M. College
Dear Sir
We have a small
parcel of land in the shape of the diagram
below, which we desire to divide in two equal
parts by a line running parallel to the
base. I have worked the example, and, as I
knew to be correct, but other parties are
not satisfied with the solution, so, it
is agreed to ask you to solve the prob-
lem for us. Please let the work remain in
full - so that the work will be as plain as
possible - I hope to return the favor

[Signature]

Yours truly C. N. Sneed

[Diagram]

A 4 chains B
24 chains
E
D 12 chains C

**Here's the transcription, as I see it, incorporating the visual details and my analysis:** I'm looking at this letterhead and trying to make sense of everything. First, the header at the top is broken into columns. There's a left column with "ALBERT MANTOOTH, President,
C. N. SNEED, Secretary.", a center column with "J. D. GANN, Cor. Secretary.", with a little scribble above "Cor." (maybe "Ex"?) and ">> OFFICE OF <<". On the right, it reads "JOSEPH KERR, Vice-President.
C. MANTOOTH, Treasurer." The main title, partially obscured by some tape or a censor bar, is "ANGELI[NA] IMMIGRATION SOCIETY." I'm sure it's Angelina. Then the date line reads "Homer, Texas, Oct 21" 1881". The letter is addressed to "Pres. James, A.M. College, Dear Sir". Then comes the body, which reads: "We have a small parcel of land in the shape of the diagram below, which we desire to divide in two equal parts by a line running parallel to the base. I have worked the example, and, as I knew to be correct, but other parties are not satisfied with the solution, so, it is agreed to ask you to solve the prob- lem for us. Please let the work remain in full - so that the work will be as plain as possible - I hope to return the favor." The signature at the bottom looks like "Yours truly C. N. Sneed," which matches the printed name. Then there is a hand-drawn diagram. It's a trapezoid. The top is labeled "A 4 chains B". There's a vertical drop on the right side labeled "24 chains". The bottom is labeled "D 12 chains C". There's a horizontal line drawn across the middle labeled "E ... F". The "F" might be a squiggle.
